awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Hybrid analog-digital schemes for joint source-channel coding of digital sources
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims at the development of novel schemes for high throughput transmission of digital sources over noisy channels for a wide range of source and channel environments. The research effort will result in significant advancements in communications systems, including the case in which the data presents temporal or spatial correlations. Since multiple data sets, such as sensor networks and medical data, present this type of structures, this project has the potential to impact society as a whole.  

The main goal of this research is to study the application of hybrid analog-digital joint source-channel coding schemes for the transmission of digital sources over noisy channels. The proposed hybrid schemes consist of two sub-blocks concatenated in parallel:  First, a digital-to-analog encoder, which will produce either real numbers or many multiple discrete points from the input bits. Second, a digital encoder, which will produce coded bits from the input bits. The key idea is to take advantage of the analog component of the hybrid scheme to achieve high throughput communications, and robustness against changes in the channel conditions, something that is challenging with standard digital channel codes. On the other hand, the use of pure digital-to-analog encoders would lead to significant error floors, with the consequent performance degradation. However, thanks to the use of the digital encoder sub-block, these error floors can be substantially reduced to achieve an excellent performance. Hybrid analog-digital practical coding systems have not been applied for the encoding of digital sources. The development of these techniques is of great interest in practical applications such as image and video coding, sensor networks and medical applications.

por.por_cntn:
This project has investigated the development and implementation of coding structures capable of protecting the information produced by discrete sources  when transmitted through noisy channels. In order to achieve high throughput transmission, traditional schemes utilize digital channel encoders producing bits that are then mapped into the transmitted symbols. This process may lead to the  loss of the dependencies existing in the sources, which degrades the achievable performance. Differently, the proposed coding structures utilize simple transformations to produce a combination of digital and analog symbols that are directly transmitted through the channel. This allows to keep much of the source dependencies in the transmitted symbols, leading to improved performance. Since multiple data sets in many fields have to be transmitted through noisy channels and present some type of dependencies (e.g., sensor networks and medical data), this project may have a broader impact on these areas.

The main outcomes of this award have been the following:

1) Development and implementation of novel coding structures, consisting of the concatenation of simple linear encoding blocks, which outperform the Shannon separation limit for the transmissions of correlated senders over a shared channel (multiple access channel). This means that the total energy required for transmission in our proposed system will be less than the theoretical bound if traditional systems are utilized. As described before, the key idea is to keep part of the correlation shared by the senders in the symbols that are transmitted over the multiple access channel.

2) Development and implementation of novel coding structures, consisting of the concatenation of simple linear encoding blocks, which approach the theoretical limits for the transmission of  multiple independent senders over a shared channel (multiple access channel). The proposed system, which has to independently encode each one of the senders, can be easily designed by properly optimizing a coding structure designed for the transmission of a single sender over a dedicated channel.

3) Development and implementation of novel non-linear coding schemes, with a graphical structure similar to that of linear codes, which, different from standard linear codes, approach the theoretical limits for the transmission of uniform sources at low signal to noise ratios. Furthermore, the proposed coding structure, properly optimized, achieves excellent performance when non-uniform sources are transmitted at high throughput through noisy channels, outperforming existing linear schemes.
